Issues.Title: fix(ivy): support module.id as @NgModule's "id" field value
Issues.Body:
Prior to this commit, the check that verifies correct "id" field type was too strict and didn't allow `module.id` as @NgModule's "id" field value. This change adds a special handling for `module.id` and uses it as @NgModule id as is. [Example of `module.id` provided by Webpack](https://webpack.js.org/api/module-variables/#moduleid-commonjs).

This PR resolves FW-1281.

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): include context name for template functions for `ng-content`
Issues.Body:
Previously, a template's context name would only be included in an embedded
template function if the element that the template was declared on has a
tag name. This is generally true for elements, except for `ng-content`
that does not have a tag name. By omitting the context name the compiler
could introduce duplicate template function names, which would fail at runtime.

This commit fixes the behavior by always including the context name in the
template function's name, regardless of tag name.

Resolves FW-1272
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(ivy): include context name for template functions for `ng-content`" (#30025)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): ngcc - insert new imports after existing ones
Issues.Body:
Previously, ngcc would insert new imports at the beginning of the file, for
convenience. This is problematic for imports that have side-effects, as the
side-effects imposed by such imports may affect the behavior of subsequent
imports.

This commit teaches ngcc to insert imports after any existing imports. Special
care has been taken to ensure inserted constants will still follow after the
inserted imports.

Resolves FW-1271
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(ivy): ngcc - insert new imports after existing ones" (#30029)

Issues.Title: feat(compiler-cli): lower some exported expressions
Issues.Body:
The compiler uses metadata to represent what it statically knows about
various expressions in a program. Occasionally, expressions in the program
for which metadata is extracted may contain sub-expressions which are not
representable in metadata. One such construct is an arrow function.

The compiler does not always need to understand such expressions completely.
For example, for a provider defined with `useValue`, the compiler does not
need to understand the value at all, only the outer provider definition. In
this case, the compiler employs a technique known as "expression lowering",
where it rewrites the provider expression into one that can be represented
in metadata. Chiefly, this involves extracting out the dynamic part (the
`useValue` expression) into an exported constant.

Lowering is applied through a heuristic, which considers the containing
statement as well as the field name of the expression.

Previously, this heuristic was not completely accurate in the case of
route definitions and the `loadChildren` field, which is lowered. If the
route definition using `loadChildren` existed inside a decorator invocation,
lowering was performed correctly. However, if it existed inside a standalone
variable declaration with an export keyword, the heuristic would conclude
that lowering was unnecessary. For ordinary providers this is true; however
the compiler attempts to fully understand the ROUTES token and thus even if
an array of routes is declared in an exported variable, any `loadChildren`
expressions within still need to be lowered.

This commit enables lowering of already exported variables under a limited
set of conditions (where the initializer expression is of a specific form).
This should enable the use of `loadChildren` in route definitions.

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): explicitly compile ngModuleDef for RootScopeModule in R3TestBed
Issues.Body:
This commit unifies the way auxiliary RootScopeModule and DynamicTestModule are compiled in R3TestBed by calling `compileNgModuleDefs` explicitly for RootScopeModule. This change also resolves the problem where TestBed's code was used from the @angular/core NPM package: due to the "jit" flag, the @NgModule decorator on the RootScopeModule was transformed to RootScopeModule.decorators = [...], but actual ngModuleDef was never defined.

This PR resolves FW-1280.

Issues.Title: feat(core): Add `TestBed.typedGet`
Issues.Body:
`TestBed.typedGet` is a non breaking change to make way for a typed
`TestBed.get` signature. This commit adds the function with a different
name and strong types.

A future commit for Angular 9.x will replace the current `TestBed.get`
signature with the one added here, and `TestBed.typedGet` will be then
marked as deprecated to be completly removed on Angular 10.x

`Injector.get` will match the same signature as `TestBed.typedGet` on
Angular 9.x, both being breaking changes added at the same time.

Issue #26491
Fixes #29905

Issues.Title: refactor(core): template-var-assignment migration incorrectly warns
Issues.Body:
Currently the `template-var-assignment` migration incorrectly warns if
the template writes to a property in the component that has the same
`ast.PropertyWrite` name as a template input variable but different
receiver. e.g.

```html
<!-- "someProp.element" will be incorrectly reported as template variable assignment -->
<button *ngFor="let element of list" (click)="someProp.element = null">
  Reset
</button>
```

Similarly if an output writes to a component property with the same name as a
template input variable, but the expression is within a different template scope,
the schematic currently incorrectly warns. e.g.

```html
<button *ngFor="let element of list">{{element}}</button>

<!-- The "element = null" expression does not refer to the "element" template input variable -->
<button (click)="element = null"></button>
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "refactor(core): template-var-assignment migration incorrectly warns" (#30026)

Issues.Title: refactor(core): static-query migration should not fail for test files
Issues.Body:
Currently when someone runs `ng update` with the static-query migration,
the migration can fail with an error saying that the `AOT` compiler could not
be created. This can happen if the CLI project contains a test `tsconfig.json`
that is picked up by the schematic.

Due to the fact that spec tsconfig files cannot be ran with NGC (e.g. test
components are not part of a module; not all source files are guaranteed to
be included), test `tsconfig` projects will now use a new `test` migration
strategy where all queries within tests are left untouched and a TODO is added.

Fixes #30031
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor(core): static-query migration should not fail for test files" (#30034)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): ngcc - do not copy declaration files into bundle clone
Issues.Body:
Previously, all of a program's files would be copied into the __ivy_ngcc__
folder where ngcc then writes its modifications into. The set of source files
in a program however is much larger than the source files contained within
the entry-point of interest, so many more files were copied than necessary.
Even worse, it may occur that an unrelated file in the program would collide
with an already existing source file, resulting in incorrectly overwriting
a file with unrelated content. This behavior has actually been observed
with @angular/animations and @angular/platform-browser/animations, where
the former package would overwrite declaration files of the latter package.

This commit fixes the issue by only copying relevant source files when cloning
a bundle's content into __ivy_ngcc__.

Fixes #29960
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(ivy): ngcc - do not copy declaration files into bundle clone" (#30020)

Issues.Title: "Could not create Angular AOT compiler to determine query timing." when updating to Angular 8
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package @angular/core. ### Is this a regression? No. ### Description A clear and concise description of the problem... When updating a project created by Angular CLI version 7, the warnings are shown. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction This error can be reproduced by following the update steps in ``` npm i -g @angular/cli@~7.0 ng new seven-oh-project cd seven-oh-project ng update @angular/cli --next ng update @angular/core --next ``` It also shows up in the CLI test suite for updates: https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/pull/14228/files#r277311238. ## üî• Exception or Error 

  Could not create Angular AOT compiler to determine query timing.
  The following diagnostics were detected:
  Cannot determine the module for class AppComponent in C:/Users/kamik/AppData/Local/Temp/angular-cli-e2e-2019322-20076-1fyaia4.k68k/assets/7.0-project-1555942786902/src/app/app.component.ts! Add AppComponent to the NgModule to fix it.
  Cannot determine the module for class LazyCompComponent in C:/Users/kamik/AppData/Local/Temp/angular-cli-e2e-2019322-20076-1fyaia4.k68k/assets/7.0-project-1555942786902/src/app/lazy/lazy-comp/lazy-comp.component.ts! Add LazyCompComponent to the NgModule to fix it.
## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** 

8.0.0-beta.13
**Anything else relevant?** Warnings seem to come from here: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/packages/core/schematics/migrations/static-queries/strategies/template_strategy/template_strategy.ts#L183-L187

Issues.Title: docs: add cross-platform support to the schematics for libraries guide
Issues.Body:
Add Windows friendly commands for copying schematics into the library.

Fixes #29952

## PR Checklist

## What is the current behavior?
<!-- Please describe the current behavior that you are modifying, or link to a relevant issue. -->
The [schematics for libraries guide](https://angular.io/guide/schematics-for-libraries) uses the `cp` command to copy schematics into the library's output directory (in the `package.json` file). The `cp` command is not a valid command in Windows cmd.exe and will throw an error it the scripts are executed.
Issue Number: 29952


## What is the new behavior?
Additional documentation explains that Windows users should use the `copy` command or look into a cross-platform solution such as [ncp](https://www.npmjs.com/package/ncp).

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): ensure that super/sub classes can both update an animation binding in harmony
Issues.Body:
In ivy, because metadata is inherited, this may cause super and sub host bindings on
two components to update an animation binding in parallel. This patch ensures that
the animation transition code can handle this.

Jira-Issue: FW-1220

Issues.Title: fix(common): suggest keyvalue pipe in error thrown when trying to use NgFor with an object
Issues.Body:
The error messaging in NgFor will now point developers toward the keyvalue pipe when they try to iterate over an object. This is valuable to developers who may not know about the new feature (introduced in 6.1).

fixes #28240

## PR Checklist
Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements:

- [ X ] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit
- [ X ] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)
- [ X ] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features)


## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

<!-- Please check the one that applies to this PR using "x". -->

- [ X ] Bugfix
- [ ] Feature
- [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables)
- [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)
- [ ] Build related changes
- [ ] CI related changes
- [ ] Documentation content changes
- [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes
- [ ] Other... Please describe:


## What is the current behavior?

When a developer tries to pass an object to NgFor, the error message does not mention the keyvalue pipe, which would allow iterating over an object's properties. 

Issue Number: 28240

## What is the new behavior?

The error handler returns the same message as before for invalid values passed into NgFor. 

If the invalid value is an object and not null, the handler will return the same error message, but with "Use the keyvalue pipe to iterate over an object's properties" appended.

## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [ X ] No

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): ngcc - prefer JavaScript source files when resolving module‚Ä¶
Issues.Body:
‚Ä¶ imports

Packages that do not follow APF may have the declaration files in the same
directory as one source format, typically ES5. This is problematic for ngcc,
as it needs to create a TypeScript program with all JavaScript sources of
an entry-point, whereas TypeScript's module resolution mechanism would have
resolved an internal module import to the external facing .d.ts declaration
file, instead of the JavaScript source file. This behavior results in the
program to be analysed being incomplete.

This commit introduces a custom compiler host that recognizes the above
scenario and rewires the resolution of a .d.ts declaration file to its
JavaScript counterpart, if applicable.

Fixes #29939
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ivy): ngcc - prefer JavaScript source files when resolving module‚Ä¶" (#30017)

Issues.Title: feat(router): Descendant projection through router.
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request ### Relevant Package This feature request is for @angular/router, @angular/core ### Description Basically, my feature request is about content projection through router tree. I'll explain with an example. Let's say I have an Tab Component which contains a basic **"two tab"** **mat-tab-nav-bar**. Also, I have two other components which contain my real page contents. In this case, my router configuration would be something like so ```typescript { path: 'identity', component: TabsComponent children: [ { path: 'tab1', component: Tab1Component }, { path: 'tab2', component: Tab2Component } ] } ``` My TabsComponent has an **@ContentChildren** query with descendants option true. TabsComponents template looks like this. ```html
Tab1 Tab2
``` So each tab component has an ng-template something like so ```html Content will be projected to anchestor component ``` ### Describe the solution you'd like Content projection should work as the current content projection works with descendant components. ### Describe alternatives you've considered My workaround. Each tab has an variable named as toolbar which has a @ViewChild('toolbar') decorator. So all tab pages takes their ng-template reference by theirselves. So TabsComponents template looks like this. ```html ... ``` Hint: Don't know whether this already solved by ivy. Thanks
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "feat(router): Descendant projection through router." (#30016)

Issues.Title: Several 8.0 Migration fixes
Issues.Body:
* The package group format required to automatically update the builder packages was not supported until CLI 7.2.  For older CLI versions performing the update, this new migration will update the builders instead.  Once the CLI is updated to at least 7.2, the update algorithm itself will handle the update.

* Skip E2E projects when migrating browserslist.  These projects are not actual applications.

Fixes #14233
Fixes #14229
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Several 8.0 Migration fixes" (#14238)

Issues.Title: 8 migration should not add `e2e/browserlist`
Issues.Body:
Projects created with CLI 7 have two default projects: `project-name` and `project-name-e2e`. But projects created with CLI 8 only have `project-name` and a `e2e` target inside it instead.

The `differential-loading` migration adds `e2e/browserslist`, but shouldn't. We should either ignore the old e2e project or roll it into `project-name` like the current configs do.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "8 migration should not add `e2e/browserlist`" (#14233)

Issues.Title: `@angular-devkit/build-angular` is not updated when updating to CLI 8
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [x] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? No. ### Description A clear and concise description of the problem... `@angular-devkit/build-angular` is not updated when updating to CLI 8 via `ng update @angular/cli`. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Can be seen in https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/pull/14228. ## üî• Exception or Error No error. ## üåç Your Environment 

Angular version 7.0.7
**Anything else relevant?**
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "`@angular-devkit/build-angular` is not updated when updating to CLI 8" (#14229)

Issues.Title: Set correct peerDependencies for TypeScript and Angular Compiler CLI
Issues.Body: In version 8, we support only Angular 8+ which only supports TypeScript >=3.4 < 3.5
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Set correct peerDependencies for TypeScript and Angular Compiler CLI" (#14236)

Issues.Title: Host.delete() completes but never emits
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Host.delete() completes but never emits" (#14235)

Issues.Title: 8 migration does not remove commented polyfills
Issues.Body:
CLI 7 projects have almost all polyfills commented out except zone.js.

The CLI 8 migration attempts to remove polyfills imports by parsing the AST, but since they are commented out they never show up.

The migration should remove these imports regardless of being commented out, since they aren't necessary anymore.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "8 migration does not remove commented polyfills" (#14234)

Issues.Title: Existing `src/browserlist` should be updated or moved
Issues.Body:
Projects created using CLI 7 have `src/browserslist`, but the migration expects it to be at root instead.

We should either update `src/browserlist` in place, or move it to root.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Existing `src/browserlist` should be updated or moved" (#14232)

Issues.Title: fix(@schematics/angular): migrate TS module type to esnext
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(@schematics/angular): migrate TS module type to esnext" (#14222)

Issues.Title: test: add 7.0 update test
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "test: add 7.0 update test" (#14228)

Issues.Title: generate classes and export it as a default
Issues.Body:
when running the following cmd:
`> ng g class test `

the generated class is
`export default class{..}`
instead of
`export class TestClass{}`
so it is more convenient when importing it
or at least add an option to the command
`> ng g class test --default-export=true `
also applied to components and other ng elements
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "generate classes and export it as a default " (#14223)

Issues.Title: xi18n doesn't emit messages.xlf with Ivy enabled
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [x] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? The issue is only present with Ivy enabled ### Description Running `ng xi18n` does not emit `messages.xlf` if the app uses Ivy. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction ``` ng new xi18n --defaults --enable-ivy cd xi18n # add i18n attribute on the h1 tag in app.component.html ng xi18n ``` ## üî• Exception or Error No error can be seen, the command runs OK: 

Hash: d2b856c9dffb86f8809b
Time: 16592ms
Built at: 21/04/2019 15:44:26
           Asset      Size         Chunks                    Chunk Names
         main.js  2.19 MiB           main  [emitted]  [big]  main
polyfills-es5.js   361 KiB  polyfills-es5  [emitted]  [big]  polyfills-es5
    polyfills.js   151 KiB      polyfills  [emitted]         polyfills
Entrypoint main [big] = main.js
Entrypoint polyfills-es5 [big] = polyfills-es5.js
Entrypoint polyfills = polyfills.js
chunk {main} main.js (main) 1.81 MiB [entry] [rendered]
chunk {polyfills} polyfills.js (polyfills) 146 KiB [entry] [rendered]
chunk {polyfills-es5} polyfills-es5.js (polyfills-es5) 193 KiB [entry] [rendered]
But not file is emmited. If you switch `enableIvy` to `false`, then the command emits `messages.xlf` again. ## üåç Your Environment 

Angular CLI: 8.0.0-beta.16
Node: 11.11.0
OS: darwin x64
Angular: 8.0.0-beta.13
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic
... router

-----------------------------------------------------------

Issues.Title: fix(autocomplete): make template ViewChild query `static: true`
Issues.Body: The `@ViewChild` query for TemplateRef here needs to be static because some code paths lead to the overlay being created before change detection has finished for this component. Notably, another component may trigger `focus` on the autocomplete-trigger.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(autocomplete): make template ViewChild query `static: true`" (#15877)

Issues.Title: Use of custom TrackByFunction in MatTree does not preserve expansion state when nodes change
Issues.Body:
#### What is the expected behavior?

Use of trackBy should also ensure that the expansion state does not get lost when nodes are updated.

#### What is the current behavior?

Use of trackBy does not ensure that the expansion state does not get lost when nodes are updated. This is presumably since TreeControl uses an expansionModel which is a SelectionModel<T> where the SelectionModel has no awareness of the TrackByFunction.

#### What are the steps to reproduce?

Relying upon the TreeControl expansionModel:
https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-5wpr9o-kjnmsn?file=app%2Ftree-flat-overview-example.ts

#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?

all

#### Is there anything else we should know?

Trying to store expansion state in the nodes themselves as a workaround doesn't work (unless you transfer the state):
https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-5wpr9o-ahptjs?file=app%2Ftree-flat-overview-example.ts

Having a custom expansionModel that is aware of the trackBy state works to preserve state, since the TreeControl's expansion-related methods apparently aren't actually used internally by the tree component:
https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-5wpr9o-pbmk1g?file=app%2Ftree-flat-overview-example.ts
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Use of custom TrackByFunction in MatTree does not preserve expansion state when nodes change" (#15872)

Issues.Title: fix(stepper): Fix visual flake in focusing stepper header
Issues.Body:
When the step is changed through a button click sometimes the focus of the new
step header is attributed by focus monitor to 'mouse' instead of 'program'. This
results in a visual difference in the step header (focus background is missing).
Instead, when focusing the step header focus it via 'program' explicitly through
the focus monitor.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(stepper): Fix visual flake in focusing stepper header" (#15870)

Issues.Title: breakpointObserver incorrectly emits when resizing
Issues.Body:
#### What is the expected behavior?
If multiple breakpoints are provided, the observer should only emit "false" if neither breakpoint is matched

#### What is the current behavior?
If multiple breakpoints are provided and quick resizing occurs, the observer sometimes emits "false" despite the size never leaving the matched range.

#### What are the steps to reproduce?
in [this stackblitz](https://stackblitz.com/edit/query-size-bug?file=src%2Fapp%2Fapp.component.ts), resize the window quickly at around 600px width. If you never go over the "Small" breakpoint size, the results of "betterLargeMatches" (which uses a single query) does not increment, but the value of `largeMatches` does sometimes increment.


#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?
Reproduced in Safari and Chrome on MacOS, using CDK 7.3.x and Angular 7.2.x. I have not tested with other versions.

#### Is there anything else we should know?
This issue is particularly bad when a layout change happens based on the breakpoint observer, and if that layout change involves adding or removing components. For example, I found this bug in a layout that has two columns at large sizes, but a mat-tab component at small sizes. This bug caused the mat-tab to reinitialize when the window was resized from XSmall to Small, which caused the state of the currently active tab to be lost.

The workaround is to create a single query that encompasses both queries (as shown in the stackblitz)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "breakpointObserver incorrectly emits when resizing" (#15868)

Issues.Title: [MatTabs] mat-tab-label width alignment
Issues.Body:
#### What is the expected behavior?
Minimal width of `.mat-tab-label` is aligned with [tabs specification](https://material.io/design/components/tabs.html#spec)

#### What is the current behavior?
current `min-width` value is set to 160px for desktop: https://github.com/angular/material2/blob/e66131744a9fa43438d8c91e682a73dec428be7b/src/lib/tabs/_tabs-common.scss#L14

and 72px for mobile:
https://github.com/angular/material2/blob/master/src/lib/tabs/tab-nav-bar/tab-nav-bar.scss#L48
https://github.com/angular/material2/blob/master/src/lib/tabs/tab-header.scss#L19

! **Specification defines it as 90px (regardless screen size)**

#### What are the steps to reproduce?
Providing a [StackBlitz](https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-material2-issue-a986j6). Make sure app width is greater then $mat-xsmall(599px)


#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?
latest
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[MatTabs] mat-tab-label width alignment" (#15864)

Issues.Title: Typing Injected Dialog Data causes compile error with aot
Issues.Body:
#### What is the expected behavior?
Compiles successfully

#### What is the current behavior?

`Metadata collected contains an error that will be reported at runtime: Expression form not supported.`

#### What are the steps to reproduce?
Create a dialog component that receives data from the caller. Typing the data will result in an error.

`
@Inject(MAT_DIALOG_DATA) public data: {user: User};
`

#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?
`
    "@angular/common": "^7.0.0",
    "@angular/core": "^7.0.0",
    "@angular/material": "^7.3.7",
    "@angular/cdk": "^7.3.7",
`

#### Is there anything else we should know?
Workaround is to remove the typing or add a // @dynamic about the component decorator.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Typing Injected Dialog Data causes compile error with aot" (#15862)

Issues.Title: [MatStepper] FormControlLike is not compatible with FormGroup
Issues.Body:
#### What is the expected behavior?
The stepControl attribute of the CdkStep/MatStep classes should be castable to/assignable from a FormGroup or FormArray.

#### What is the current behavior?
`Conversion of type 'FormControlLike' to type 'FormGroup' may be a mistake because neither type sufficiently overlaps with the other. If this was intentional, convert the expression to 'unknown' first.
Property 'controls' is missing in type 'FormControlLike'.`
Happens during compilation when trying to cast FormControlLike to a FormGroup.

```Type FormGroup is not assignable to type FormControlLike```
Is the warning shown in HTML files when trying to assign a FormGroup to the stepControl input of a MatStep.

#### What are the steps to reproduce?
Create a MatStepper with a FormGroup assigned to a stepControl of one of the MatSteps. To reproduce the compilation issue, try to cast the stepControl of one step into a FormGroup within a TypeScript function.


#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?
Material Version 7.3.7
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[MatStepper] FormControlLike is not compatible with FormGroup" (#15859)

Issues.Title: Virtual scroller doesn't disconnect DataSource when destroyed
Issues.Body:
#### What is the expected behavior?
If the cdkVirtualFor's data input is a DataSource, it should be disconnected upon directive's destruction.

#### What is the current behavior?
If the cdkVirtualFor's data input is a DataSource, it's never disconnected upon directive's destruction.

#### What are the steps to reproduce?
Just open this [stackblitz](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fstackblitz.com%2Fedit%2Fangular-r7faxt&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AFQjCNGcIMIlM24RETc_INmfoYL9uhFhPg) and toggle virtual scroller in and out of the view multiple times. Check the console, and you'll only see the data source connection messages. It never gets disconnected. This will cause leaks if, for example, the data source subscribes to some service in order to fetch data from backend.

#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?
The very last Angular Material v7.3.7.

#### Is there anything else we should know?
This is the piece of code, related to the data source disconnection logic:

![scroller](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/34121107/56340795-b1b94b00-61bb-11e9-990a-b725cba2e726.png)

And here's a [link](https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Fgithub.com%2Fangular%2Fmaterial2%2Fblob%2Fmaster%2Fsrc%2Fcdk%2Fscrolling%2Fvirtual-for-of.ts%23L269&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AFQjCNHcGvIsWTegNK0YauLgEvv_i9KyUg) to this snippet. It's the only place where the data source gets disconnected. In other words, the data source is only disconnected if the data source changes. Hence the issue, mentioned above:  the disconnect() method isn't called upon directive's destruction.

If there's nothing I'm missing it should be easy to fix - the data source should be disconnected in cdkVirtualFor's **ngOnDestroy** method if the input is a DataSource.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Virtual scroller doesn't disconnect DataSource when destroyed" (#15855)

Issues.Title: [MatIcon] can not be embedded in SVGs
Issues.Body:
#### Bug, feature request, or proposal:
Bug

#### What is the expected behavior?
MatIcon or equivalent should be able to be embedded via an ng-container tag so that SVG
icons render only SVG tags.

#### What is the current behavior?

Mat icons are always surrounded by a <mat-icon> tag which prevents svgIcons from rendering
when embedded in an svg.

#### What are the steps to reproduce?

https://material2-issue-15045-ijytdc.stackblitz.io

#### What is the use-case or motivation for changing an existing behavior?

We are building a SVG based visualization library in Angular and I would rather not create my
own icon component. SVG icons should be embeddable in an SVG.

#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?

All

#### Is there anything else we should know?

Th example has an inherited svg-icon component that I created. Because of some of the
internals of mat-icon I would rather material provide a fix instead of my app having to deal with breaking changes.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[MatIcon] can not be embedded in SVGs" (#15854)
